abstract: Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, has early onset Alzheimer’s. On Sunday, she led the Lady Volunteers to victory and won an award for courage.
snippet: Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, has early onset Alzheimer’s. On Sunday, she led the Lady Volunteers to victory and won an award for courage.
lead_paragraph: The coach who is most credentialed in her sport to speak her mind and was never shy about expressing herself no longer addresses the news media after a game. Such is the new abnormal for Pat Summitt and her famous Tennessee women’s basketball team.

abstract: Dr. Williams was a former director of the National Institute on Aging and a longtime professor at the University of Rochester.
snippet: Dr. Williams was a former director of the National Institute on Aging and a longtime professor at the University of Rochester.
lead_paragraph: Dr. T. Franklin Williams, a former director of the National Institute on Aging and an early proponent of geriatric care as a medical specialty, died at his home in Rochester on Nov. 25, the day before his 90th birthday.

abstract: Researchers initiate an effort to understand how patients cope after learning they have cognitive problems.
snippet: Researchers initiate an effort to understand how patients cope after learning they have cognitive problems.
lead_paragraph: How would you react to a diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment — memory problems that allow you to continue normal daily activities, but presage an increased likelihood of developing Alzheimer’s disease within a few years?
headline.main: It’s Mild Cognitive Impairment. Now What?

abstract: Tom Brown was unseeded but made it to the semifinals at Wimbledon in 1946, and later dominated senior amateur play.
snippet: Tom Brown was unseeded but made it to the semifinals at Wimbledon in 1946, and later dominated senior amateur play.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brown, who reached the men’s singles final of United States Tennis Championships at Forest Hills in 1946 and at Wimbledon in 1947, losing both times to Jack Kramer, died Oct. 27 in Castro Valley, Calif. He was 89.

abstract: The judge in the case of Liliane Bettencourt based her decision on a medical evaluation that indicated the heiress suffers from dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
snippet: The judge in the case of Liliane Bettencourt based her decision on a medical evaluation that indicated the heiress suffers from dementia and Alzheimer's disease.
lead_paragraph: Liliane Bettencourt, the aging heiress of the L’Oréal cosmetics fortune, was placed under the care of a legal guardian Monday by a judge, who based the decision on a medical evaluation that indicated she suffers from dementia and Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: French Court Puts L'Oréal Heiress Under Guardianship
headline.print_headline: France: Heiress Loses Control of Fortune

lead_paragraph: For the Betancur family, it was a kind of pilgrimage, an act of faith in science.

abstract: A shoe with a hidden G.P.S. device may help caregivers find wandering family members.
snippet: A shoe with a hidden G.P.S. device may help caregivers find wandering family members.
lead_paragraph: I hear from lots of publicists touting technology products that supposedly help older adults, and I ignore most of the gizmos they’re promoting. Without a skilled and unbiased Consumer Reports-type lab to test these inventions — and could someone please create one soon? — it’s too hard to tell which actually work well.
headline.main: A Shoe for Wanderers

abstract: On Tuesday, a committee meets in Washington to begin putting together a national plan to fight Alzheimer’s disease. You are cordially invited.
snippet: On Tuesday, a committee meets in Washington to begin putting together a national plan to fight Alzheimer’s disease. You are cordially invited.
lead_paragraph: People concerned about Alzheimer’s disease and its effect on families, on the health care system, on the country as a whole, have lobbied for years for a national action plan. How should the nation confront a disease projected to afflict more than 13 million Americans by 2050 — a disease gaining on cancer as the illness Americans dread most?
headline.main: Coming Soon: A National Strategy on Alzheimer’s

abstract: Television evangelist Pat Robertson has sparked controversy with his suggestion that a man could divorce his wife with Alzheimer’s once she no longer recognized him.
snippet: Television evangelist Pat Robertson has sparked controversy with his suggestion that a man could divorce his wife with Alzheimer’s once she no longer recognized him.
lead_paragraph: The television evangelist Pat Robertson has sparked controversy with his suggestion that a man could divorce his wife with Alzheimer’s once she no longer recognized him.
headline.main: Love, Divorce and Alzheimer’s

abstract: Other Christian leaders condemned Pat Robertson for suggesting that a man may divorce his wife if she has Alzheimer’s, while some caregivers were more understanding.
snippet: Other Christian leaders condemned Pat Robertson for suggesting that a man may divorce his wife if she has Alzheimer’s, while some caregivers were more understanding.
lead_paragraph: With his suggestion this week that a man whose wife was far “gone” with Alzheimer’s should divorce her if he wanted a new companion, the television evangelist Pat Robertson stumbled into treacherous moral terrain, setting off storms of criticism and questions about a disease that shatters lives and families.

abstract: An intriguing study suggests that aerosolized insulin may help people who are in the early stages of Alzheimer’s.
snippet: An intriguing study suggests that aerosolized insulin may help people who are in the early stages of Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: A small pilot study has found preliminary evidence that squirting insulin deep into the nose where it travels to the brain might hold early Alzheimer’s disease at bay, researchers said on Monday.
headline.main: A Squirt of Insulin May Delay Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: A Squirt Of Insulin May Delay Alzheimer’s

abstract: Aerosolized insulin seemed to help Alzheimer’s patients in a small pilot study, researchers said on Monday.
snippet: Aerosolized insulin seemed to help Alzheimer’s patients in a small pilot study, researchers said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: A small experimental pilot study has found preliminary evidence that aerosolized insulin, squirted deep into the nose, might hold early Alzheimer’s disease at bay, The Times reported on Monday. Read the full article, “Squirts of Insulin May Delay Alzheimer’s,” and share your thoughts in the comments section.
headline.main: Scientists Pursue an Unusual Tactic Against Alzheimer’s

abstract: A care facility in New Jersey is home for Ron Johnson, a former Giants running back who was found to have Alzheimer’s disease in 2008.
snippet: A care facility in New Jersey is home for Ron Johnson, a former Giants running back who was found to have Alzheimer’s disease in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Ron Johnson’s private room is large but sparse: a couch, two chairs, a flat-screen television and a computer that has been programmed to accommodate Johnson’s favorite games: chess, backgammon, poker.

abstract: An evangelist sets off a furor by suggesting that it’s appropriate to divorce a spouse with dementia.
snippet: An evangelist sets off a furor by suggesting that it’s appropriate to divorce a spouse with dementia.
lead_paragraph: The question from a viewer of “The 700 Club” had likely crossed the minds of hundreds of thousands of people experiencing the slow and inevitable loss of a spouse to Alzheimer’s disease or another dementia. Could a healthy partner justify a relationship with someone else as a demented spouse declined?

abstract: For millions with a neurological condition called mild cognitive impairment, lapses in word-finding and name recall are often common.
snippet: For millions with a neurological condition called mild cognitive impairment, lapses in word-finding and name recall are often common.
lead_paragraph: Who hasn’t struggled occasionally to come up with a desired word or the name of someone near and dear? I was still in my 40s when one day the first name of my stepmother of 30-odd years suddenly escaped me. I had to introduce her to a friend as “Mrs. Brody.”

abstract: Tennessee thought Pat Summitt should continue coaching despite early-onset Alzheimer’s because of her experienced assistants and what she meant to the university.
snippet: Tennessee thought Pat Summitt should continue coaching despite early-onset Alzheimer’s because of her experienced assistants and what she meant to the university.
lead_paragraph: Mickie DeMoss had been away from the Tennessee women’s basketball program for seven years, working as a head coach and an assistant elsewhere, when she gave in to Pat Summitt’s entreaties to come back last year as an assistant. It was a chance to go home, to return to the place she had worked for 18 years for her beloved mentor. But when DeMoss started work, she was immediately struck by changes she saw in Summitt.

abstract: Fellow coaches were stunned by Pat Summitt’s diagnosis of dementia but hardly surprised that the Tennessee Lady Vols coach approached it in her signature way — head-on, open, and resolute.
snippet: Fellow coaches were stunned by Pat Summitt’s diagnosis of dementia but hardly surprised that the Tennessee Lady Vols coach approached it in her signature way — head-on, open, and resolute.
lead_paragraph: When Pat Summitt became head coach of the Tennessee Lady Vols in 1974, she drove the team van and began to shift gears on the long uphill climb for women’s sports.

abstract: Scientists have calculated that if people address certain risks, a significant number of Alzheimer’s cases could be prevented, with the operative word being “could.”

lead_paragraph: Is there a way to prevent Alzheimer’s disease? Last week, a study presented at the Alzheimer’s Association International Conference in Paris suggested there might be, something that would give hope to millions who worry that one day they may be struggling with dementia.

abstract: The writers of “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” discuss the science and ethical issues behind the hit film.
snippet: The writers of “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” discuss the science and ethical issues behind the hit film.
lead_paragraph: 6:35 p.m. | Updated Last weekend, I took my two sons, 13 and 21, to see “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” which we thoroughly enjoyed on several levels. It’s a rousing slave revolt, an entertaining techno-thriller, a drama about a dysfunctional household (chimp included) dealing with disability and job-related stresses (in the conflicted genetic engineer played by James Franco). (Manohla Dargis liked it, too, as did my sons’ favorite critics, the team at Spill.com.

abstract: This haunting first novel’s deeply unreliable narrator is a former surgeon with Alzheimer’s and the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder.
snippet: This haunting first novel’s deeply unreliable narrator is a former surgeon with Alzheimer’s and the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder.
lead_paragraph: Unreliable narrators come in many shapes. There are madmen, mystics, seducers, naïfs — Nabokov’s Humbert Humbert, the ghost-prone governess in “The Turn of the Screw” and Poe’s self-defeating paranoiac in “The Tell-Tale Heart,” for starters. And then there is Dr. Jennifer White, who narrates Alice LaPlante’s first novel. By the time “Turn of Mind” begins, she is losing her wits to Alzheimer’s disease and is the prime suspect in her best friend’s murder. She is as unreliable as they come.

abstract: A study showed that people who had diabetes or high blood pressure at the beginning of the study were more likely to have signs of brain deterioration and lower mental function 13 years later.
snippet: A study showed that people who had diabetes or high blood pressure at the beginning of the study were more likely to have signs of brain deterioration and lower mental function 13 years later.
lead_paragraph: Cardiovascular risk factors in middle age are associated with brain deterioration and a decline in mental function later in life, a new report has found.
headline.main: Risks: Heart Risks May Hasten Mental Decline
headline.print_headline: Risks: Heart Risks May Hasten Mental Decline

abstract: Jack Agüeros, who directed El Museo del Barrio for almost a decade, has forgotten that he is the author of four books, a handful of plays, sonnets and satiric psalms about poverty and social inequality.
snippet: Jack Agüeros, who directed El Museo del Barrio for almost a decade, has forgotten that he is the author of four books, a handful of plays, sonnets and satiric psalms about poverty and social inequality.
lead_paragraph: The memory of the New York poet Jack Agüeros is capricious nowadays. He remembers the lyrics of certain Puerto Rican folk songs and the name of his petite, growling dog: Nikki. He does not remember collecting the old radios, locks and cast-iron pieces that once decorated his bright Manhattan apartment on West 14th Street.
headline.main: Slowly, Alzheimer’s Erases a Poet’s Gifts and Memories

abstract: For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance.
snippet: For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance.
lead_paragraph: For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance. Activity appears to be critical, though scientists have yet to prove that exercise can ward off serious problems like Alzheimer’s disease. But what about the more mundane, creeping memory loss that begins about the time our 30s recede, when car keys and people’s names evaporate? It’s not Alzheimer’s, but it’s worrying. Can activity ameliorate its slow advance — and maintain vocabulary retrieval skills, so that the word “ameliorate” leaps to mind when needed?
headline.main: How Exercise Can Keep the Brain Fit

abstract: On Tuesday, the National Institute on Aging is releasing new medical guidelines radically recasting what it means to have Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: On Tuesday, the National Institute on Aging is releasing new medical guidelines radically recasting what it means to have Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning that for the first time in 27 years, Alzheimer’s disease is being redefined in new medical guidelines reflecting mounting evidence that the disease ravages the brain years before symptoms of dementia appear.
headline.main: Alzheimer’s, Redefined

abstract: Researchers on Tuesday reported progress toward the development of two tests to screen adults for Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Researchers on Tuesday reported progress toward the development of two tests to screen adults for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have made further progress on two tests designed to detect Alzheimer’s disease, The Times reported on Tuesday. An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration this week will determine whether one of these tests, a brain scan, should be marketed for widespread use. The other screening tool, a blood test, is still in the earliest stages of development.
headline.main: Screening for Alzheimer’s

abstract: A neurologist spends decades trying to dodge Alzheimer’s disease — and fails.
snippet: A neurologist spends decades trying to dodge Alzheimer’s disease — and fails.
lead_paragraph: In Tuesday’s Science Times, the writer Nancy Stearns Bercaw describes her father’s decades-long preoccupation with preventing Alzheimer’s disease, which had killed her grandfather. Alzheimer’s was the reason her father became a neurologist in the first place, she writes: he “knew it was coming.”
headline.main: Resisting Alzheimer’s

abstract: The definition of the disease will be recast for the first time in 27 years, with a division into three stages, including a new early phase.
snippet: The definition of the disease will be recast for the first time in 27 years, with a division into three stages, including a new early phase.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 27 years, the definition of Alzheimer’s disease is being recast in new medical guidelines that reflect fast-mounting evidence that it begins ravaging the brain years before the symptoms of dementia.
headline.main: Guidelines Allow Earlier Definition of Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: New Guidelines Offered To Diagnose Alzheimer’s

abstract: What are the most important concerns about caregiving and the patient with Alzheimer’s disease?
snippet: What are the most important concerns about caregiving and the patient with Alzheimer’s disease?
lead_paragraph: In a recent New York Times article, “Giving Alzheimer’s Patients Their Way, Even Chocolate,” I looked at caregiving for people with Alzheimer’s disease and described how scientists and researchers are studying approaches to caregiving that appear to ease some of the most troubling symptoms, like wandering or agitated and aggressive behavior. Certain approaches to caregiving can make life more pleasant for patients, who, research suggests, continue to feel emotions like joy or sadness even if they have no memory of the experiences that caused those emotions. And they can, in turn, make things easier for caregivers, allowing people to care for relatives with Alzheimer’s at home and delay placing them in nursing homes.
headline.main: Caring for the Patient With Alzheimer’s

abstract: Dr. Gary Kennedy, a geriatric psychiatrist, on those revised medical guidelines for diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Dr. Gary Kennedy, a geriatric psychiatrist, on those revised medical guidelines for diagnosing Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The newly revised criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, the first change since 1984 in how this dementia is diagnosed, are likely to be most valuable at first to scientists and researchers. The guidelines spring in part from novel research into biomarkers and imaging techniques that may not reach family medical practices for some time.
headline.main: Remaking Alzheimer’s: A Few Questions

abstract: New York Times science reporter Gina Kolata responds to reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: New York Times science reporter Gina Kolata responds to reader questions about Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The two largest studies ever of Alzheimer’s disease have led to the discovery of five new genes that increase risk of the disease, Gina Kolata reports in today’s New York Times. There are now 10 genes that are known to increase the risk of Alzheimer’s in old age.
headline.main: Ask About Alzheimer’s Disease

abstract: In a strategy that disregards typical nursing-home rules, the Beatitudes nursing home in Phoenix allows patients practically anything that brings comfort.
snippet: In a strategy that disregards typical nursing-home rules, the Beatitudes nursing home in Phoenix allows patients practically anything that brings comfort.

snippet: On Thursday, an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended approval of a new dye that can reveal brain plaques characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease in living patients.
lead_paragraph: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously Thursday that the agency approve the first test able to diagnose Alzheimer’s disease in the brain of a living person, The Times reports this morning.

abstract: A new study contributes to growing evidence that the chances of inheriting Alzheimer’s from your mother are higher than from your father.
snippet: A new study contributes to growing evidence that the chances of inheriting Alzheimer’s from your mother are higher than from your father.
lead_paragraph: Alzheimer’s disease is more common in people whose mothers had the illness than in those whose fathers had it  and the evidence can be found in the brains of people who are still healthy.

lead_paragraph: Jim Nantz had a master plan: his father would retire from his furniture business and join him on the road at N.F.L. games, golf tournaments and college basketball arenas. The elder Nantz, who was also named Jim, would help manage and organize his son’s busy life on the road.

abstract: After analyzing the genes of more than 50,000 people in the United States and Europe, researchers discover five genes that make Alzheimer’s somewhat more likely in the elderly.
snippet: After analyzing the genes of more than 50,000 people in the United States and Europe, researchers discover five genes that make Alzheimer’s somewhat more likely in the elderly.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning that two enormous studies have linked five genes to the development of Alzheimer’s disease. The associations are not strong — each gene confers an increase in risk of just 10 to 15 percent — but they should help point researchers to new mechanisms underlying this dementia.
headline.main: Scientists Link New Genes to Alzheimer’s

abstract: The two largest studies of Alzheimer’s disease led to the discovery of five genes that provide intriguing new clues to why it strikes and how it progresses.
snippet: The two largest studies of Alzheimer’s disease led to the discovery of five genes that provide intriguing new clues to why it strikes and how it progresses.
lead_paragraph: The two largest studies of Alzheimer’s disease have led to the discovery of no fewer than five genes that provide intriguing new clues to why the disease strikes and how it progresses.

abstract: A committee voted that the agency approve the first test that can show Alzheimer’s in the brain of a living person.
snippet: A committee voted that the agency approve the first test that can show Alzheimer’s in the brain of a living person.
lead_paragraph: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended unanimously Thursday that the agency approve the first test  a brain scan  that can show the characteristic plaques of Alzheimer’s disease in the brain of a living person. The approval was contingent on radiologists agreeing on what the scans say and doctors being trained in how to read the scans.

lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Margaret Nance was, to put it mildly, a difficult case. abstract: In a major shift in attitude that reflects the challenges of an aging population, China is starting to publicly confront dementia.
snippet: In a major shift in attitude that reflects the challenges of an aging population, China is starting to publicly confront dementia.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Last year, an expensive, red-brick residential complex opened here, equipped with a hair salon, cinema, toy-cluttered game rooms and a karaoke suite offering the latest in pop music.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ron Reagan’s new memoir, “My Father at 100,” has touched off sensational headlines with its suggestion that President Ronald Reagan might have begun showing hints of Alzheimer’s disease while still in the White House.

abstract: Among those participants with vascular problems, those who received care were almost 40 percent less likely to develop Alzheimer’s than those who did not.
snippet: Among those participants with vascular problems, those who received care were almost 40 percent less likely to develop Alzheimer’s than those who did not.
lead_paragraph: Older people suffering from mild memory and cognition problems may be less likely to progress to full-blown Alzheimer’s disease if they receive treatment for medical conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure and cholesterol, a new study has found.
headline.main: Patterns: Treating Other Conditions May Stave Off Alzheimer’s, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: PATTERNS: Treating Vascular Ills May Curb Alzheimer’s

abstract: A runny nose, fallen arches and a need to wear dentures aren’t risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a person’s risk for dementia.
snippet: A runny nose, fallen arches and a need to wear dentures aren’t risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a person’s risk for dementia.
lead_paragraph: A runny nose, fallen arches and dentures aren’t risk factors typically associated with brain health. But new research suggests that small health problems can add up, and the combined effect can increase a person’s risk for dementia.
headline.main: Small Health Woes Increase Dementia Risk

abstract: The Icelandic director, screenwriter, producer and occasional actor Fridrik Thor Fridriksson finds himself in the running for a second Oscar nomination, this time for “Mamma Gogo,” a film about a film whose hopes for breaking even hinge on receiving an Oscar nomination.
snippet: The Icelandic director, screenwriter, producer and occasional actor Fridrik Thor Fridriksson finds himself in the running for a second Oscar nomination, this time for “Mamma Gogo,” a film about a film whose hopes for breaking even hinge on receivi...
lead_paragraph: Imagine a film that is about a film whose hopes for breaking even financially hinge on its receiving an Oscar nomination. Then imagine that the film — the real one, not the film within the film — actually ends up in contention for an Oscar.
headline.main: From Iceland, a Meta-Comedy About Movies and Alzheimer’s

abstract: Among other benefits, the regular use of two languages appears to delay the onset of Alzheimer’s disease symptoms.
snippet: Among other benefits, the regular use of two languages appears to delay the onset of Alzheimer’s disease symptoms.
lead_paragraph: A cognitive neuroscientist, Ellen Bialystok has spent almost 40 years learning about how bilingualism sharpens the mind. Her good news: Among other benefits, the regular use of two languages appears to delay the onset of Alzheimer’s disease symptoms. Dr. Bialystok, 62, a distinguished research professor of psychology at York University in Toronto, was awarded a $100,000 Killam Prize last year for her contributions to social science. We spoke for two hours in a Washington hotel room in February and again, more recently, by telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows.

abstract: Primary progressive aphasia is one of several forms of brain disease lost in the medical shadow of a much better known relative, Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Primary progressive aphasia is one of several forms of brain disease lost in the medical shadow of a much better known relative, Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Steve Riedner of Schaumburg, Ill., was a 55-year-old tool-and-die maker, a job that involves difficult mental calculations, and a frequent speaker at community meetings when he found himself increasingly at a loss for words and unable to remember numbers. He even began to have difficulty reading his own written comments.

abstract: With a little help, my mother remembered my birthday. But what if one day she cannot remember me?
snippet: With a little help, my mother remembered my birthday. But what if one day she cannot remember me?
lead_paragraph: When I got up, Mom was already awake. I could hear her rummaging in the kitchen. Through the glass doors in the living room, sunlight flared so brightly off the hillocks of snow that I had to shield my eyes.
headline.main: Forgetting the Gift

lead_paragraph: The Times reports today on research into new ways to care for people with Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia.

abstract: What happens if an older doctor’s skills begin to slip because of early Alzheimer’s or another illness, putting the patient at risk?
snippet: What happens if an older doctor’s skills begin to slip because of early Alzheimer’s or another illness, putting the patient at risk?
lead_paragraph: A third of the physicians in the United States are over 65, and many continue to work with competence into their 70s and beyond. Yet what happens if a doctor’s cognitive or physical skills begin to slip because of early Alzheimer’s, a subtle stroke or another illness, putting the patient at risk? That’s a question explored by Laurie Tarkan in this week’s Science Times.
headline.main: When Older Doctors Put Patients at Risk

abstract: Dr. Richard J. Hodes, the director of the National Institute on Aging, weighs the research his lab is doing in a time of fiscal pressure.
snippet: Dr. Richard J. Hodes, the director of the National Institute on Aging, weighs the research his lab is doing in a time of fiscal pressure.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard J. Hodes presides over the nation’s prime source of grants for studies of aging at a worrisome time for researchers. Just when the cohort of elderly Americans is surging, many scientists fear that government budget cuts may hamper a broad array of research efforts on Alzheimer’s and other diseases of aging  not to mention the eye-catching recent progress on reversing age-related decline in genetically altered mice.

abstract: Staying active will give Pat Summitt, the women’s basketball coach at Tennessee, the best chance to stave off decline and give Alzheimer’s a public face.
snippet: Staying active will give Pat Summitt, the women’s basketball coach at Tennessee, the best chance to stave off decline and give Alzheimer’s a public face.
lead_paragraph: Just after an earthquake rolled through the world of sports on Tuesday, an earthquake rolled through the East Coast. The timing seemed fitting, suggesting perhaps even tectonic plates relied on the idea that Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, was indestructible. Having watched her will her way to so many things, lifting not only her own program and women’s basketball to a new level, but also women’s sports. Certainly she wasn’t subject to things like the law of gravity or human illnesses like Alzheimer’s, right?
headline.main: Summitt’s New Opponent
headline.print_headline: Summitt Opts Not to Give In

abstract: Mr. Burton won several Emmys for his productions, which focused on the struggle for African-American equality and the inner workings of American government,
snippet: Mr. Burton won several Emmys for his productions, which focused on the struggle for African-American equality and the inner workings of American government,
lead_paragraph: Philip Burton Jr., who wrote, produced and directed award-winning television documentaries about the struggle for African-American equality and the inner workings of American government, died on Dec. 24 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 76 and lived in Ojai, Calif.

abstract: In “Turn of Mind,” Alice LaPlante offers a haunting portrait of a woman suffering from dementia.
snippet: In “Turn of Mind,” Alice LaPlante offers a haunting portrait of a woman suffering from dementia.
lead_paragraph: It can’t be coincidence that as more of us confront the anguish of dementia, artists are becoming intrigued with shifting memory and altered personality, with dementia’s deeply unsettling effect on the self and on others.
headline.main: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: A Doctor’s Decline

abstract: Much of the budget mess may stem from a deep cultural antipathy toward recognizing our own mortality.
snippet: Much of the budget mess may stem from a deep cultural antipathy toward recognizing our own mortality.
lead_paragraph: I hope you had the chance to read and reread Dudley Clendinen’s splendid essay, “The Good Short Life,” in The Times’s Sunday Review section. Clendinen is dying of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S. If he uses all the available medical technology, it will leave him, in a few years’ time, “a conscious but motionless, mute, withered, incontinent mummy of my former self.”

abstract: Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, said she hoped to manage the disease and planned to coach in the coming season.
snippet: Pat Summitt, the Tennessee women’s basketball coach, said she hoped to manage the disease and planned to coach in the coming season.
lead_paragraph: Pat Summitt, the longtime women’s basketball coach at Tennessee who has won more games than any other major college coach, said she forgot things at crucial points in games at times last season and struggled to keep track of when meetings were scheduled. She grew so confused that on a few days she simply stayed home from work.

abstract: Her son, Anthony D. Marshall, and Francis X. Morrissey Jr. were found guilty of defrauding Mrs. Astor, a victim of Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Her son, Anthony D. Marshall, and Francis X. Morrissey Jr. were found guilty of defrauding Mrs. Astor, a victim of Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The lawyers for Brooke Astor’s son and for a lawyer who did estate planning for her filed a lengthy appeal to their convictions on Monday.

abstract: Faced with the possibility that their parents have grown too confused to manage their own finances, many adult children turn to physicians. But often they are ill equipped to help cope with an elderly patient’s financial problems.
snippet: Faced with the possibility that their parents have grown too confused to manage their own finances, many adult children turn to physicians. But often they are ill equipped to help cope with an elderly patient’s financial problems.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Miller first became alarmed when her mother began complaining during their phone conversations. “I’m spending so much money,” she fretted. “I can’t figure out why I don’t have any money.” This was a departure: Ms. Miller’s mother, always responsible about her finances, never liked talking about them. Ms. Miller wondered what was going on.

abstract: How The Times reported on Dr. Jack Kevorkian’s first assisted suicide.
snippet: How The Times reported on Dr. Jack Kevorkian’s first assisted suicide.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the central, controversial figure in the national debate over assisted suicide, died last week at age 83 in a hospital outside of Detroit. He first assisted in a suicide in 1990, connecting Janet Adkins, a 54-year-old woman suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, to a device of his own invention. The Times’s Lisa Belkin reported as follows:

abstract: The bride is the founder of an ice cream store; the bridegroom is a founder of a publisher of digital travel guides.
snippet: The bride is the founder of an ice cream store; the bridegroom is a founder of a publisher of digital travel guides.
lead_paragraph: Robyn Sue Goldman, the daughter of Jill S. Goldman and Dr. Lee Goldman of New York, is to be married Sunday to Tobin Joseph Fisher, the son of Gerry A. Fisher and Marshall L. Fisher of Penn Valley, Pa. Jeff Goldman, a brother of the bride, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate at Holman Ranch in Carmel Valley, Calif.

abstract: Etta James, the seminal R&B singer, is terminally ill, according to her doctor, Elaine James (who is not related to Etta James).
snippet: Etta James, the seminal R&B singer, is terminally ill, according to her doctor, Elaine James (who is not related to Etta James).
lead_paragraph: Etta James, the seminal R&B singer, is terminally ill, according to her doctor, Elaine James  (who is not related to Etta James). Dr. James told The Press-Enterprise in Riverside, Calif., that family members were told two weeks ago that Ms. James’s chronic leukemia could not be cured. “I am Southern and Christian and would just ask for the prayers of her fans and friends,” Dr. James said. “They know she’s been sick, but not how sick.” Etta James, 73, has been among the most celebrated American blues singers for decades, recording enduring hits like “At Last,” “Tell Mama” and “I’d Rather Go Blind.” She was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993. Her career was also influenced by drug addiction, troubled love relationships and health and legal problems. In 2010 she was hospitalized for a staph infection, and it became public that she was suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, and that she had been treated for dependence on painkillers. Dr. James has cared for Etta James, above, at her home in Riverside since March 2010, and she made the statements last week outside a hearing over control of Ms. James’s $1 million estate. Donato James, her son, has been fighting in court with her husband, Artis Mills, over who will be named the estate’s conservator.
headline.main: Etta James Is Terminally Ill
headline.print_headline: Etta James Is Terminally Ill
byline.original: Compiled by James C. McKinley Jr

abstract: A new type of brain scan may help accurately identify Parkinson’s disease, but it will not be cheap and effective therapies are still lacking.
snippet: A new type of brain scan may help accurately identify Parkinson’s disease, but it will not be cheap and effective therapies are still lacking.
lead_paragraph: Karen Alexander says she is “one of the lucky ones.” Ten years after learning she has Parkinson’s disease, she takes two drugs to control her symptoms and so far has few of them. A tremor on her left side can make it hard to balance a teacup and saucer, but “at 74, it doesn’t bother me much,” she said. Luckily, Ms. Alexander, who lives in a suburb west of Chicago, is right-handed.
headline.main: A Portrait of Parkinson’s Disease

abstract: The director Asghar Farhadi says his “Separation,” which opens in New York and Los Angeles on Dec. 30, is about “human problems,” not politics.
snippet: The director Asghar Farhadi says his “Separation,” which opens in New York and Los Angeles on Dec. 30, is about “human problems,” not politics.
lead_paragraph: Traveling around North America and Europe this year for festival showings of their new movie, “A Separation,” the Iranian director Asghar Farhadi and his cast have discerned a pattern. Audiences arrive skeptical, anticipating something exotic and unfamiliar, and leave pleasantly surprised that they understand and can identify with the film’s characters.

abstract: Isa Leshko, a fine art photographer, set out to capture glimpses of animals in their twilight years — a therapeutic project inspired by caring for her mother with Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Isa Leshko, a fine art photographer, set out to capture glimpses of animals in their twilight years — a therapeutic project inspired by caring for her mother with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: It is not hard to argue that we live in a youth-centric culture, one in which young age and beauty are almost synonymous. And that obsession does not end with humans. Puppies and kittens melt hearts; images and videos of baby animals flood the Internet. But rarely does an image of an animal in old age ignite the same interest and adoration.
headline.main: What We Can Learn From Old Animals

abstract: Dr. Charles J. Epstein, best known for his work on Down syndrome, was seriously injured in a 1993 mail bomb attack by Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomber.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Charles J. Epstein, a prominent medical geneticist who in 1993 was seriously injured in an attack by the Unabomber but was later able to continue his research on Down syndrome and other genetic conditions, died on Feb. 15 at his home in Tiburon, Calif. He was 77.

abstract: Gary Bettman, the N.H.L. commissioner, defended the physical nature of professional hockey and cautioned against connecting any dots between the brain disease C.T.E. and fighting.
snippet: Gary Bettman, the N.H.L. commissioner, defended the physical nature of professional hockey and cautioned against connecting any dots between the brain disease C.T.E. and fighting.
lead_paragraph: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — The N.H.L. board of directors met for three and a half hours Tuesday and never broached the subject of fighting, Commissioner Gary Bettman said. Fighting is an aspect of the game that has come under scrutiny by others in the wake of the recent deaths of three of the game’s enforcers.

abstract: Most people say they’ll pay for genetic tests even if the predictions are sometimes wrong, and most people don’t seem to be traumatized even when they receive bad news.
snippet: Most people say they’ll pay for genetic tests even if the predictions are sometimes wrong, and most people don’t seem to be traumatized even when they receive bad news.
lead_paragraph: When companies tried selling consumers the results of personal DNA tests, worried doctors and assorted health experts rushed to the public’s rescue. What if the risk assessments were inaccurate or inconsistent? What if people misinterpreted the results and did something foolish? What if they were traumatized by learning they were at high risk for Alzheimer’s or breast cancer or another disease?

abstract: Despite tight credit, some developers are building new retirement and assisted-living housing to take advantage of a market in which demand now outstrips supply.
snippet: Despite tight credit, some developers are building new retirement and assisted-living housing to take advantage of a market in which demand now outstrips supply.
lead_paragraph: EAST NORTHPORT, N.Y. — When the housing market collapsed in 2008, construction of retirement and assisted-living housing ground to a halt, just as it did in most commercial real estate sectors, as access to capital evaporated. But a few companies kept their development teams intact in the recession, and are now building new facilities and expanding their operations. And as lending loosens, they say, they are poised to benefit from the housing needs of America’s aging population.

abstract: Mr. Pihos helped take the Philadelphia Eagles to two consecutive N.F.L. championships in the 1940s.
snippet: Mr. Pihos helped take the Philadelphia Eagles to two consecutive N.F.L. championships in the 1940s.
lead_paragraph: Pete Pihos could do just about anything on a football field. A member of both the College and Pro Football Halls of Fame, he was an outstanding pass-catcher, a powerful runner and a formidable blocker, helping to take the Philadelphia Eagles to two consecutive National Football League championships in the 1940s.

abstract: The United States will continue to fall behind unless it changes old habits and practices.
snippet: The United States will continue to fall behind unless it changes old habits and practices.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Americans who once believed they owned the future now look warily across the Pacific to an emerging China that is building the world's largest network of high-speed trains, taking over the solar industry and producing the highest-scoring students on international tests.
headline.main: How to Get America Back on Track
headline.print_headline: How to Get America Back on Track

abstract: Mr. Robbins, with Paul Nordoff, designed a brand of music therapy for hard-to-reach children that is now used to help people with autism, stroke and Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Mr. Robbins, with Paul Nordoff, designed a brand of music therapy for hard-to-reach children that is now used to help people with autism, stroke and Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Clive Robbins, a developer of an influential brand of music therapy designed to help people with various disabilities meet the physical, mental and social challenges that are facts of everyday life, died on Wednesday at his home in Jersey City. He was 84.

abstract: The one-man show “Mad Women” at the Club at La MaMa finds John Fleck reflecting on his childhood.
snippet: The one-man show “Mad Women” at the Club at La MaMa finds John Fleck reflecting on his childhood.
lead_paragraph: After the countless drag queens who have paid tribute to Judy Garland, you’d think her stardust might be running low. But no, the actor and performance artist John Fleck grabs a handful in his spirited, heartfelt, one-man show “Mad Women” at the Club at La MaMa. Mr. Fleck and three other artists — Karen Finley, Holly Hughes and Tim Miller — were at the center of a controversy over content in the early 1990s when the National Endowment for the Arts revoked their grants. There is no controversy in “Mad Women,” only affection for Garland and bittersweet recollections of Mr. Fleck’s past.

abstract: Ms. Love, who often played ingénues on Broadway in the 1950s, originated the part of Rosa in a Tennessee Williams play.
snippet: Ms. Love, who often played ingénues on Broadway in the 1950s, originated the part of Rosa in a Tennessee Williams play.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Love, who often played ingénues on Broadway in the 1950s and who originated the part of Rosa Delle Rose in Tennessee Williams’s “Rose Tattoo,” died on Oct. 30 at her home in Menifee, Calif. She was 85.

abstract: As a dancer, Mr. Reigenborn was the epitome of the deceptively cool Minimalist style that emerged in the dance avant-garde of the 1970s.
snippet: As a dancer, Mr. Reigenborn was the epitome of the deceptively cool Minimalist style that emerged in the dance avant-garde of the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Garry Reigenborn, a dancer and choreographer who played an influential role in American experimental dance as a leading member of the Lucinda Childs Dance Company and as a teacher of Merce Cunningham’s technique, died on March 10 in Canon City, Colo. He was 58.
headline.main: Garry Reigenborn, a Dancer and Influential Choreographer, Dies at 58
headline.print_headline: Garry Reigenborn, 58, a Dancer and Influential Choreographer

abstract: Photographers at The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times have won Pulitzers this year.
snippet: Photographers at The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times have won Pulitzers this year.
lead_paragraph: Carol Guzy, Nikki Kahn and Ricky Carioti of The Washington Post have won the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for their coverage of the catastrophic Haitian earthquake. And Barbara Davidson of The Los Angeles Times has won the Pulitzer in feature photography for chronicling the victims of gang violence.

lead_paragraph: In 1973, a little boy named Mikey, a notoriously picky eater, dug enthusiastically into a bowl of a new, healthy cereal called Life. “He likes it!” his stunned older brother exclaimed in a memorable 30-second commercial that ran for over a decade.

abstract: In the U.S. budget battle, it looks like the next target is the National Institutes of Health, despite the fact that many say that America's economic destiny is reliant on scientific innovation.
snippet: In the U.S. budget battle, it looks like the next target is the National Institutes of Health, despite the fact that many say that America's economic destiny is reliant on scientific innovation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Barack Obama’s call for “investments” in education, infrastructure and science and health research is dismissed by most congressional Republicans as a fig leaf for more big-government spending.

abstract: “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” is both an origin story for its 1968 predecessor, “Planet of the Apes,” and an amusingly cheerful film about the end of humanity.
snippet: “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” is both an origin story for its 1968 predecessor, “Planet of the Apes,” and an amusingly cheerful film about the end of humanity.
lead_paragraph: “Rise of the Planet of the Apes,” an amusingly cheerful film about the end of humanity that’s PETA and critic approved — no animals were harmed in its making, and neither was James Franco’s career — is precisely the kind of summer diversion that the studios have such a hard time making now. It’s good, canny-dumb fun. Employing bleeding-edge technologies in the service of old-fashioned entertainment, it insists on the emotional truth of its absurd story, its tongue in cheek (and in check), while offering self-aware asides, like the ritual bow to Charlton Heston, the lockjaw hero of the original 1968 “Planet of the Apes.”

abstract: Three music therapists from MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care crisscross the city and suburbs to sing songs to the dying.
snippet: Three music therapists from MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care crisscross the city and suburbs to sing songs to the dying.
lead_paragraph: Every week, three music therapists from MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care crisscross the city and suburbs to sing songs to the dying. With guitars strapped to their backs, a flute or tambourine and a songbook jammed in their backpacks, they play music for more than 100 patients, in housing projects, in nursing homes and even in a lavish waterfront home. The time for chemotherapy and radiation is over.
headline.main: Relaxing, Touching the Memory, Music Helps With the Final Transition
headline.print_headline: Relaxing, Touching the Memory, Music Helps With the Final Transition

abstract: Experts are always urging family members to “redirect” people with dementia, rather than point out their errors or argue with them. Sometimes that’s not so easy.
snippet: Experts are always urging family members to “redirect” people with dementia, rather than point out their errors or argue with them. Sometimes that’s not so easy.
lead_paragraph: Leila Arnett, 94, moved into a nursing home in Louisville, Ky., last summer. She’s having a hard time — congestive heart failure, aortic stenosis, trouble hearing and seeing, general frailty. She recognizes visiting family members and can make conversation, but her dementia is causing delusions.
headline.main: Packing Away a Delusion

abstract: Because the structure and plot points of “Unforgettable” are so familiar, its success depends largely on the appeal of its star, Poppy Montgomery.
snippet: Because the structure and plot points of “Unforgettable” are so familiar, its success depends largely on the appeal of its star, Poppy Montgomery.
lead_paragraph: Stop me if this sounds familiar: A former police detective who left the force after being unable to get over or solve the murder of a loved one is still a valuable consultant to the police because of freakish powers of observation, and is still driven by a determination to find that loved one’s killer.

abstract: Ms. Girardot, who played the doomed Milanese streetwalker in Luchino Visconti’s “Rocco and His Brothers,” moved easily from drama to comedy.
snippet: Ms. Girardot, who played the doomed Milanese streetwalker in Luchino Visconti’s “Rocco and His Brothers,” moved easily from drama to comedy.
lead_paragraph: Annie Girardot, a versatile French actress who played the doomed Milanese streetwalker in Luchino Visconti’s “Rocco and His Brothers” and, moving easily from drama to comedy, became France’s most popular actress of the 1970s, died on Monday in Paris. She was 79.

abstract: The mother and wife of prime ministers was an important figure in her own right.
snippet: The mother and wife of prime ministers was an important figure in her own right.
lead_paragraph: Nusrat Bhutto, a near-mythic figure in Pakistan’s modern history, whose husband, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was executed in 1979 after being deposed as prime minister in a military coup, and whose daughter Benazir Bhutto, a former prime minister, was killed by a suicide bomber while campaigning for office in 2007, died Sunday in Dubai. She was 82.

abstract: Mr. Schaeberle, who worked at Nabisco for 40 years, led the company through two mergers.
snippet: Mr. Schaeberle, who worked at Nabisco for 40 years, led the company through two mergers.
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Schaeberle, who led Nabisco through two mergers but retired as chairman and chief executive in 1986 as the company moved toward one of the biggest and most contentious leveraged buyouts in Wall Street history, died on Sept. 29 at an assisted living facility in Exeter, N.H. He was 88.

abstract: This week we pair the poem “Mysterious Neighbors” with a blog post, “Guns in Frail Hands.”
snippet: This week we pair the poem “Mysterious Neighbors” with a blog post, “Guns in Frail Hands.”
lead_paragraph: In our weekly “Poetry Pairing” series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poem’s themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.
headline.main: Poetry Pairing | Feb. 17, 2011

abstract: Dr. Arthur Horwich, a winner of this year’s Lasker Award, has discovered a “changing room” for proteins that allows them to do their jobs.
snippet: Dr. Arthur Horwich, a winner of this year’s Lasker Award, has discovered a “changing room” for proteins that allows them to do their jobs.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Medicine is a divided world. On one side are the doctors, who come face to face with illness each day and try to heal their patients with whatever tools they can get their hands on. On the other are the researchers, who explore the body’s microscopic complexity, never sure whether their discoveries will ever end up in the hands of the doctors.

abstract: Susan Jacoby challenges the optimistic marketing that has made old age seem pleasant and carefree.
snippet: Susan Jacoby challenges the optimistic marketing that has made old age seem pleasant and carefree.
lead_paragraph: Susan Jacoby has long made it her project to uncover ill-formed, cynical “junk thought” and administer a cold dose of reason and logic against it. But Jacoby is no Mr. Spock. Her rationalism is delivered in an angry barrage peppered with enthusiastically snide asides. In previous books, including “The Age of American Unreason” and “Freethinkers,” her targets have been right-leaning religionists, social Darwinists, and the paucity of reason in a generation that stares too much at glowing screens and too little at learned books. In her latest jeremiad, “Never Say Die,” she fights to slay the conspiracies of ignorance and greed that she believes conceal a single, and indeed irrefutable, truth: extreme old age can be nasty, brutish and long.

abstract: An outdoorsman tired of running and slipping on icy Minnesota roads created the NordicTrack, a cross-country skiing simulator.
snippet: An outdoorsman tired of running and slipping on icy Minnesota roads created the NordicTrack, a cross-country skiing simulator.
lead_paragraph: Ed Pauls, whose frustration at running on ice-slick Minnesota roads led him to develop the cross-country skiing simulator known as the NordicTrack, died on Oct. 9 at his home in Montrose, Colo. He was 80.

abstract: A filmmaker looks beyond the myth to find the man.
snippet: A filmmaker looks beyond the myth to find the man.
lead_paragraph: Your new documentary, “Reagan,” which makes its premiere on HBO on Feb. 7 in honor of the president’s 100th birthday, includes some wonderful footage of Reagan as a small-town lifeguard, a handsome figure in his swimming trunks who happened to be severely nearsighted. Did you intend that as some kind of metaphor?  That’s exactly right. He had certain blind spots in his priorities but an absolutely genuine desire to be a person who could save people’s lives. No question.

abstract: The president will honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today and meet with China’s president, Hu Jintao, this week.

abstract: Despite a Standard & Poor’s warning that the rating of Europe’s bailout fund would be tied to those of its guarantor countries, investors sent markets mostly higher.
snippet: Despite a Standard & Poor’s warning that the rating of Europe’s bailout fund would be tied to those of its guarantor countries, investors sent markets mostly higher.
lead_paragraph: Stocks rose on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index higher a second day, on speculation that European leaders may act to contain the debt crisis after S.& P. put 15 euro nations on review for possible downgrade.

abstract: Johnson was a brawny but agile runner who had a Hall of Fame career that spanned 13 professional football seasons.
snippet: Johnson was a brawny but agile runner who had a Hall of Fame career that spanned 13 professional football seasons.
lead_paragraph: John Henry Johnson, a brawny but agile runner and a powerful blocker who starred for the San Francisco 49ers, the Detroit Lions and the Pittsburgh Steelers in a Hall of Fame career spanning 13 professional football seasons, died Friday in Tracy, Calif. He was 81.

lead_paragraph: David E. Rumelhart, whose computer simulations of perception gave scientists some of the first testable models of neural processing and proved helpful in the development of machine learning and artificial intelligence, died Sunday in Chelsea, Mich. He was 68.

abstract: Light therapy is typically recommended for seasonal affective disorder, but more patients with depression may benefit from the treatment.
snippet: Light therapy is typically recommended for seasonal affective disorder, but more patients with depression may benefit from the treatment.
lead_paragraph: Antidepressants like Prozac and Paxil are widely used to treat depression, but a much less costly alternative called bright light therapy, in which a patient sits under an artificial light for a set period of time each day, is not. Light therapy is typically recommended for seasonal affective disorder, the “winter blues” brought on by shorter days and limited sun. Some psychiatrists prescribe it for this condition, often as a last resort when patients fail to respond to drugs.

abstract: Larry Jones stopped training horses two years ago, but renewed health and a star filly, Havre de Grace, have him in the Breeders’ Cup Classic.
snippet: Larry Jones stopped training horses two years ago, but renewed health and a star filly, Havre de Grace, have him in the Breeders’ Cup Classic.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Two years ago Larry Jones pulled his white cowboy hat over his eyes and rode off the racetrack and into the sunset, swearing he was done training horses. He was cranky on his way out, too, blaming his owners and their incessant demands for taking all the joy out of the only thing he had ever wanted to do.

abstract: Jerry Sandusky could have waived his hearing long before his alleged victims had arrived at the courthouse.
snippet: Jerry Sandusky could have waived his hearing long before his alleged victims had arrived at the courthouse.
lead_paragraph: To the series of sorry spectacles that has been the Jerry Sandusky/Penn State child sexual abuse scandal, we add one of the sorriest yet. To call Tuesday’s preliminary hearing-that-wasn’t a circus would be insulting the actual circus. Under this metaphorical big top, Sandusky’s lawyer all but stood on top of a car with a bullhorn urging everyone to come attend his client’s hearing — including dragging in a set of alleged victims who had to skewer up the courage to testify in open court — and then waived the hearing after they’d all arrived.

abstract: Trapit, a start-up that opens to the public Tuesday, offers a new way to search the Web for topics by using machine learning. It is trying to provide an alternative to Google’s search engine and link sharing on Facebook and Twitter.
snippet: Trapit, a start-up that opens to the public Tuesday, offers a new way to search the Web for topics by using machine learning. It is trying to provide an alternative to Google’s search engine and link sharing on Facebook and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Though Web search is dominated by Google and supplemented by link-sharing on Facebook and Twitter, a start-up, Trapit, which opens to the public Tuesday, thinks it can offer a smarter, more personalized way to search for topics.

abstract: Ms. Davis, beloved in England for continuing her performances during the bombing of London during World War II, later performed with Sinatra and the big bands of Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller.
snippet: Ms. Davis, beloved in England for continuing her performances during the bombing of London during World War II, later performed with Sinatra and the big bands of Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller.
lead_paragraph: Beryl Davis, a British singer who was beloved in England for carrying on with her cabaret performances during the bombing of London in World War II, and who later performed with Frank Sinatra and the big bands of Benny Goodman and Glenn Miller, died on Friday in Los Angeles. She was 87.

abstract: Dr. McCulloch was involved in the discovery of stem cells and thereby opening a path of research that some day may help treat a variety of serious, sometimes lethal, ailments.
snippet: Dr. McCulloch was involved in the discovery of stem cells and thereby opening a path of research that some day may help treat a variety of serious, sometimes lethal, ailments.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ernest A. McCulloch, a father of the stem cell research that scientists say holds promise for the treatment of many ailments, died on Jan. 20 in Toronto. He was 84.

abstract: Ms. Fickett was well known to viewers of “All My Children” and received a Tony nomination for her role as Eleanor Roosevelt in the play “Sunrise at Campobello.”
snippet: Ms. Fickett was well known to viewers of “All My Children” and received a Tony nomination for her role as Eleanor Roosevelt in the play “Sunrise at Campobello.”
lead_paragraph: Mary Fickett, who acted in theater, film and prime-time television before becoming a legend among followers of the daytime drama “All My Children” as Ruth Martin, a nurse unafraid to speak her mind, died on Thursday at her home in Callao, Va. She was 83.

abstract: Debating sex selection and abortion with the author of “Unnatural Selection”
snippet: Debating sex selection and abortion with the author of “Unnatural Selection”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Unnatural Selection” has kindly written a reply to my column on her book. Not surprisingly, she takes exception to my suggestion that sex-selective abortion poses a problem for pro-choice liberals, arguing that there’s no contradiction at all between supporting abortion rights and trying to restrict/ban abortions based on sex:
headline.main: A Response to Mara Hvistendahl (I)

abstract: A Google team’s self-driving cars have traveled nearly 200,000 miles on public highways in California and Nevada, 100 percent safely.
snippet: A Google team’s self-driving cars have traveled nearly 200,000 miles on public highways in California and Nevada, 100 percent safely.
lead_paragraph: The Jetsons had them in the 1960s. They were the defining element of “Knight Rider” in the 1980s: cars that drive themselves. Self-driving cars appear in countless science fiction movies. By Hollywood standards, they are so normal we don’t even notice them.

abstract: Sportswriters examined 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh’s overzealous postgame handshake, and Lions Coach Jim Schwartz’s reaction to it.
snippet: Sportswriters examined 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh’s overzealous postgame handshake, and Lions Coach Jim Schwartz’s reaction to it.
lead_paragraph: Today’s talk will, of course, be all about the handshake. When 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh grabbed Lions Coach Jim Schwartz’s hand and gave him an overzealous jerk, prompting Schwartz to chase him down maniacally as they left the field Sunday, it became the perfect sports story for this era. It’s easy to argue about, was captured fully on video that can be replayed endlessly and is entirely silly. It had no impact on how the game turned out, much less anything deeper or more meaningful. Which means it will be debated until the N.F.L. can provide you another distraction. (Tim Tebow is starting next week!)

abstract: If we allow that the right to die exists, the arguments for confining it to the dying seem arbitrary at best.
snippet: If we allow that the right to die exists, the arguments for confining it to the dying seem arbitrary at best.
lead_paragraph: The case for assisted suicide seems to depend on human sympathy — on the impulse toward mercy, the desire to ease what seems like pointless pain and suffering. Why shouldn’t the terminally ill meet death on their own terms, rather than at the end of prolonged agonies? Why shouldn’t the dying depart this earth with dignity, instead of enduring the inexorable stripping away of their physical and mental faculties?

headline.main: Dr. Kevorkian’s Victims
headline.print_headline: Dr. Kevorkian’s Victims

abstract: America needs to adjust its message to college graduates.
snippet: America needs to adjust its message to college graduates.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few weeks, America’s colleges have sent another class of graduates off into the world. These graduates possess something of inestimable value. Nearly every sensible middle-aged person would give away all their money to be able to go back to age 22 and begin adulthood anew.

abstract: Eduardo Nunez will soon assume the role of understudy when shortstop Derek Jeter returns to the lineup.
snippet: Eduardo Nunez will soon assume the role of understudy when shortstop Derek Jeter returns to the lineup.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In about 10 days, Derek Jeter is expected to return from the disabled list, at which point Eduardo Nunez will again assume his role of dutiful understudy. This, he knows, is not some Wally Pipp situation. “We’ll go back to the same way,” Nunez said with a laugh.
headline.main: Nunez Fills In for Jeter With Hits, Errors, Hope

abstract: The business he helped start on a shoestring in 1949 now has annual sales of more than $9 billion and 550,000 clients, and is one of the largest providers of business services.
snippet: The business he helped start on a shoestring in 1949 now has annual sales of more than $9 billion and 550,000 clients, and is one of the largest providers of business services.
lead_paragraph: Henry Taub, a founder of the payroll company that grew into the global giant Automatic Data Processing, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 83 and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

abstract: Ms. Scott, who called herself the world’s second-oldest teenager, covered rock music for The Cleveland Plain Dealer from 1964 until 2002, when she was almost 83.
snippet: Ms. Scott, who called herself the world’s second-oldest teenager, covered rock music for The Cleveland Plain Dealer from 1964 until 2002, when she was almost 83.
lead_paragraph: It was the singular combination of Kleenex, peanut butter, a shower cap and earplugs that let Jane Scott thrive in her chosen field for nearly 40 years.

abstract: There has been incredible innovation in information technology, but the pace of change has slowed in other sectors.
snippet: There has been incredible innovation in information technology, but the pace of change has slowed in other sectors.
lead_paragraph: Let’s imagine that someone from the year 1970 miraculously traveled forward in time to today. You could show her one of the iPhones that Steve Jobs helped create, and she’d be thunderstruck. People back then imagined wireless communication (Dick Tracy, Star Trek), but they never imagined you could funnel an entire world’s worth of information through a pocket-sized device.

abstract: Mr. Ellin helped bring about the reluctant marriage between the conservative world of art museums and the wild frontier of information technology.
snippet: Mr. Ellin helped bring about the reluctant marriage between the conservative world of art museums and the wild frontier of information technology.
lead_paragraph: Until the mid-20th century, the world’s greatest artworks were cataloged in shoeboxes. Then along came the computer, and for the first time, museums had a more efficient way to organize their holdings than the boxfuls of dog-eared index cards that had served them for generations.

abstract: Westchester County is to be the home of new assisted-living facilities and a continuing-care community.
snippet: Westchester County is to be the home of new assisted-living facilities and a continuing-care community.
lead_paragraph: AFTER a several-year hiatus, four assisted-living facilities and a continuing-care retirement community are finally being developed in Westchester County, an underserved market with a large and rapidly growing population of wealthy elderly residents, builders say.

abstract: The country’s choice for an Oscar this year is “Carancho,” which like last year’s winner, “The Secret In Their Eyes,” is a thriller starring Ricardo Darín.
snippet: The country’s choice for an Oscar this year is “Carancho,” which like last year’s winner, “The Secret In Their Eyes,” is a thriller starring Ricardo Darín.
lead_paragraph: The surprise winner in last year’s Oscar competition for best-foreign-language film was “The Secret in Their Eyes,” an Argentine neo-noir thriller starring Ricardo Darín. The Argentine submission this year? “Carancho,” a neo-noir thriller starring Ricardo Darín.
headline.main: A Sequel for Argentine Noir?

abstract: Induced pluripotent stem cells appear to have the healing potential of embryonic stem cells without the controversy, but when given to mice, they didn’t survive the immune response.
snippet: Induced pluripotent stem cells appear to have the healing potential of embryonic stem cells without the controversy, but when given to mice, they didn’t survive the immune response.
lead_paragraph: In an unexpected setback to efforts to harness a promising new type of stem cell to treat diseases, researchers reported on Friday that tissues made from those stem cells might be rejected by a patient’s immune system — even though the tissues would be derived from the same patient.
headline.main: Setback for New Stem Cell Treatment
headline.print_headline: Noncontroversial Type of Stem Cells Failed a Key Test, Researchers Report

abstract: In Dana Spiotta’s novel, a woman struggles with the loss of her brother, an unrecognized rock star.
snippet: In Dana Spiotta’s novel, a woman struggles with the loss of her brother, an unrecognized rock star.
lead_paragraph: A Google search of “Stone Arabia” reveals that it’s a small town in upstate New York populated primarily by the Amish. Why it was chosen as the title of Dana Spiotta’s third novel (her previous novel, “Eat the Document,” was a finalist for the National Book Award in 2006) isn’t clear until the book’s final 20 pages. In the meantime, the title rides along quietly on the cover, evocative, mysterious, incongruously poetic. So too is the narrative identity of the novel, which shifts fluidly from first to third person, from one sibling’s voice and point of view to another’s. The brother and sister at the heart of the book are Nik and Denise Kranis, who came of age in Los Angeles in the 1970s and are now in their late 40s; the novel is set in 2004, the year Denise loses her brother.

abstract: Leading Off: Will the N.H.L. and hockey fans react to knowing the details of the life and death of Derek Boogaard?
snippet: Leading Off: Will the N.H.L. and hockey fans react to knowing the details of the life and death of Derek Boogaard?
lead_paragraph: As the final installment in the story of the life and death of the hockey enforcer Derek Boogaard by The Times’s John Branch rolls out Tuesday, the waiting begins. Waiting to see if the sport reacts to something that has laid out the devastating effects of fighting in painful detail. Waiting to see if fans will continue to cheer fights, knowing they are likely trading those players’ brains for their entertainment. Waiting to see if pundits can still manage to proffer the absurd arguments about the violence preventing more violence.

abstract: Mrs. Ribicoff, the widow of Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, straddled the worlds of New York politics, fashion and culture.
snippet: Mrs. Ribicoff, the widow of Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, straddled the worlds of New York politics, fashion and culture.
lead_paragraph: Not long after doctors had determined in 1994 that Ronald Reagan was suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, his wife, Nancy, found an unexpected ally. Casey Ribicoff was coping with the same mental decline in her husband, Abraham A. Ribicoff, the resolutely liberal former senator from Connecticut.

abstract: On a single day, I came across a half-dozen family caregivers, all in various stages of exasperation.
snippet: On a single day, I came across a half-dozen family caregivers, all in various stages of exasperation.
lead_paragraph: Each year, the numbers get bigger. There are 42 million family caregivers now, a cohort that includes more than just adult children watching over their aged parents, although they predominate. Tens of millions of us are engaged in this hard, transformative task; this dance in which who leads and who follows changes by the minute; this time in life that can’t be over quickly enough and that we want to last forever; this labor of love.
headline.main: We Are Everywhere

abstract: For the first time scientists showed that, in mice at least, exercise spurs the development of mitochondria in brain cells and may make the brain more fit, similar to the way exercise makes muscles stronger.
snippet: For the first time scientists showed that, in mice at least, exercise spurs the development of mitochondria in brain cells and may make the brain more fit, similar to the way exercise makes muscles stronger.
lead_paragraph: Can exercise make the brain more fit? That absorbing question inspired a new study at the University of South Carolina during which scientists assembled mice and assigned half to run for an hour a day on little treadmills, while the rest lounged in their cages without exercising.
headline.main: How Exercise Can Strengthen the Brain

abstract: Multiple relocations are surprisingly common and often harmful to the elderly. Poor communication regarding medical needs is often to blame, experts say.
snippet: Multiple relocations are surprisingly common and often harmful to the elderly. Poor communication regarding medical needs is often to blame, experts say.
lead_paragraph: For five years, Jim Casparie pleaded with his parents, Robert and Virginia Casparie, to accept more help. His father, then 91, had Alzheimer’s disease, and his mother, 84, had diabetes and poor balance, falling frequently. When they finally agreed to move to an independent living apartment in 2008, Mr. Casparie, 61, an investment banker, thought at last he could stop worrying about their safety.

abstract: The collegiate player of the year in 1949 and first N.B.A. All-Star Game M.V.P., he was traded from the Boston Celtics to the St. Louis Hawks for Bill Russell.
snippet: The collegiate player of the year in 1949 and first N.B.A. All-Star Game M.V.P., he was traded from the Boston Celtics to the St. Louis Hawks for Bill Russell.
lead_paragraph: Ed Macauley was voted the national college basketball player of the year in 1949 and the most valuable player in the N.B.A.’s first All-Star Game in 1951. The second-highest-paid player in the N.B.A. in the early 1950s, he made the all-star team in 7 of his 10 pro seasons.

abstract: In her memoir “Then Again,” Diane Keaton entwines her story with that of her mother.
snippet: In her memoir “Then Again,” Diane Keaton entwines her story with that of her mother.
lead_paragraph: Diane Keaton’s book about her life is not a straight-up, chronological memoir. It’s a collage that mixes Ms. Keaton’s words with those of her mother, Dorothy Deanne Keaton Hall, who died in 2008. Since Ms. Hall left behind 85 scrapbooklike journals, a huge and chaotic legacy, there is every reason to expect that Ms. Keaton’s braiding of her own story with her mother’s in “Then Again” will be a rambling effort at best.

abstract: Holding a full-time job and taking care of an ill or elderly family member doesn’t have to be overwhelming.
snippet: Holding a full-time job and taking care of an ill or elderly family member doesn’t have to be overwhelming.
lead_paragraph: Q. You find yourself having to care for an ill family member while holding down a full-time job. How can you handle both of these demanding duties without feeling overwhelmed?

abstract: Centenarians in a new study smoked, ate and drank just as much as their shorter-lived counterparts. They were just as likely to be overweight, and may even have exercised less. So what contributed to their unusually long lives?
snippet: Centenarians in a new study smoked, ate and drank just as much as their shorter-lived counterparts. They were just as likely to be overweight, and may even have exercised less. So what contributed to their unusually long lives?
lead_paragraph: For those of us relying on healthy habits to get us to age 100, the findings from a new study of centenarians may come as a bit of a blow.

abstract: “My Generation,” which was nominated for a daytime Emmy, is bringing attention to the age group that watches more TV than any other.
snippet: “My Generation,” which was nominated for a daytime Emmy, is bringing attention to the age group that watches more TV than any other.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday, the TV show “My Generation,” which runs weekly on PBS, lost the daytime Emmy for outstanding lifestyle programming. Its competition was fierce: “The Nate Berkus Show,” from Oprah’s home design guy; the Style Network’s “How Do I Look?” and “The Martha Stewart Show,” which took home the trophy. But for “My Generation,” a show created by AARP, and aimed at viewers 50 and older, it was truly an honor just to be nominated.

headline.main: Leave the Tusks, Take the Cannoli

abstract: Marty McSorley says he sustained more concussions from the normal contact of playing hockey than from his numerous brawls.
snippet: Marty McSorley says he sustained more concussions from the normal contact of playing hockey than from his numerous brawls.
lead_paragraph: Marty McSorley is no stranger to hockey violence. He fought 273 times in a 17-year N.H.L. career. In 2000, he was convicted of assault after swinging his stick at the head of Donald Brashear, another feared enforcer, and was suspended for a year, effectively ending his career. He had numerous concussions as a player and today, at 47, has memory loss and other symptoms often associated with brain injury.

abstract: 64 Perry Street, next door to the town house that “Sex and the City” fans still pose in front of, was home to a couple who met in 1944 and saw the West Village as a place where being gay was accepted.
snippet: 64 Perry Street, next door to the town house that “Sex and the City” fans still pose in front of, was home to a couple who met in 1944 and saw the West Village as a place where being gay was accepted.
lead_paragraph: The house where Carrie Bradshaw lived, supposedly on the Upper East Side but actually at 66 Perry Street in the West Village, still draws a steady stream of “Sex and the City” fans. They snap photos of the row house, which was built in 1866, as if to partake in the fictional life of a New York writer and the foibles of her quest for lasting romance.
